Award.AwardTitle: Workshop on partial differential equations and several complex variables
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides funding to help cover the travel expenses of participants from the U.S. in the "Workshop on partial differential equations and several complex variables" that will be held August 3 - 7, 2015, in Serra Negra, Brazil.

The workshop will focus on recent developments in closely related areas of analysis and geometry, namely, several complex variables, overdetermined systems of partial differential equations, and CR geometry. Two mini-courses designed for graduate students and recent Ph.D.'s will form an important part of the workshop. The first mini-course will be taught by Mei-Chi Shaw who will lecture on Cauchy-Riemann equations in complex manifolds. The second mini-course will be on semi global solvability of complex vector fields and it will be taught by Abdelhamid Meziani. The workshop will provide opportunities for graduate students and recent Ph.D.'s to present and discuss their research results.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The workshop focused on recent developments in several complex variables, Cauchy Riemann manifolds and closely related areas of partial differential equations. Some of the talks were devoted to questions of solvability and regularity of solutions of systems of partial differential equations that are relevant to the study of Cauchy Riemann manifolds and several complex variables. There were also talks that demonstrated powerful methods from harmonic analysis and microlocal analysis which have proved very useful in solving many problems in several complex variables and partial differential equations. 

The workshop included two minicourses on solvability of partial differential equations and the Cauchy Riemann equations on complex manifolds by two leading researchers. These two minicourses were designed for graduate students and researchers at an early stage of their career and they provided an opportunity to raise several open questions for future research. 

An afternoon was devoted to a poster session where graduate students presented their work and were able to exchange ideas with leading experts. The workshop also provided an opportunity to postdocs to present and discuss their work.

There are several joint projects between U.S. mathematicians and their Brazilian counterparts, many of which started in these series of workshops. Among the participants from the U.S., six of them have ongoing collaborations with various researchers in Brazil. The workshop promoted these collaborations.
